Host plant.
Spencer ( 1963 )
recorded
Liriomyza braziliensis
(=
L. biformata
) mining tubers of
Solanum
( Solanaceae ).

Diagnosis. This species can be distinguished from other Neotropical
Liriomyza
by its large size, large epistoma, first flagellomere brownish apically, prescutellar area yellow to level of second dc, mid tibial seta present, mostly yellow legs except for fore coxa, which is sometimes narrowly brown basally, and sometimes brown striations on the fore femur.

Comments . The holotype of
Liriomyza braziliensis
(synonymized here with
L. biformata
) is overall paler in colour, with the orbit, first flagellomere and fore coxa completely yellow, the vti is on yellow, the anepisternum and katepisternum are more extensively yellow, and the scutellum mostly yellow with the brown lateral patch reaching the basal scutellar setae (
Fig. 36
). The scutellum of the
L. biformata
holotype (♀) and the male specimen from Napo have the scutellum narrowly yellow (
Fig. 35
), while in
Liriomyza ecuadorensis (Frost)
(synonymized with
L. braziliensis
by
Frick, 1952
), the yellow stripe is slightly wider (
Fig. 37
).
Spencer ( 1963 )
discussed the overall colour differences between the various specimens he had examined, but he did not mention the colour of the scutellum; he dissected and examined specimens attributable to
L. ecuadorensis
and
L. braziliensis
from Ecuador , Brazil and Colombia , and concluded that they all belong to the same species with the darker forms occurring at higher elevations in the Andes.

Although
Spencer ( 1963 )
mentioned that
Liriomyza braziliensis (Frost)
had two presutural dc, examination of the holotype confirms that it has only one presutural dc as in
L. biformata
. The holotype of
L. ecuadorensis
also has only one presutural dorsocentral seta (not two as mentioned by
Spencer 1963
). The comparison of the male genitalia of the holotype of
L. braziliensis
(
Figs. 38–41
) with holotype of
L. biformata
from Napo (
Figs. 42–43
) confirms that they belong to the same species. We thus conclude that these external differences are not significant, and we synonymize
L. braziliensis
with
L. biformata
.
